calm.how_stressed: How stressed are you right now?
calm.advice_low: You seem calm. Great! Keep doing what you're doing. üòä
calm.advice_medium: Getting a bit tense. Try a short breathing exercise.
calm.advice_high: High stress. Take a break now. Try breathing or one of the strategies.
calm.advice_critical: Very high stress. Press the emergency button or go to breathing. You are safe. üíô
calm.emergency_msg: Take 5 deep breaths. Count each one. You are safe. Everything will be okay.
letter.title: Letter Journey
letter.mode.explore_desc: Tap letters to hear name, sound, and see mouth position
letter.mode.find_desc: Listen to a sound and find the right letter
letter.mode.soundout_desc: Break words into individual letter sounds
letter.mode.syllable_desc: Tap syllables to practice rhythm and stress
letter.speed_hint: Start slow ‚Äî speed up as you improve (DTTC principle)
letter.explore_instruction: üî§ Tap a letter to see and hear it!
letter.soundout_instruction: üìñ Sound out each letter in the word!
letter.syllable_instruction: ü•Å Tap each syllable ‚Äî like clapping the rhythm!
letter.name: Name
letter.credit: Based on DTTC principles (Strand, 2020) for childhood apraxia of speech. Not a substitute for speech therapy.
letter.mouth.a: Open wide ‚Äî like at the dentist
letter.mouth.b: Press lips together, then pop open
letter.mouth.c: Teeth together, tongue behind bottom teeth
letter.mouth.d: Tongue tip touches behind top teeth
letter.mouth.f: Top teeth on bottom lip, blow air
letter.mouth.g: Back of tongue touches soft palate
letter.mouth.h: Open mouth, breathe out warm air
letter.mouth.i: Big smile ‚Äî lips wide, tongue high
letter.mouth.k: Back of tongue touches soft palate, release with a pop
letter.mouth.l: Tongue tip behind top teeth, voice on
letter.mouth.m: Press lips together, hum through nose
letter.mouth.n: Tongue behind top teeth, hum through nose
letter.mouth.p: Press lips together, then puff of air
letter.mouth.r: Tongue curls up ‚Äî the trickiest sound!
letter.mouth.s: Teeth close, tongue behind bottom teeth, hiss like a snake
letter.mouth.t: Tongue tip taps behind top teeth quickly
letter.mouth.u: Lips pushed forward, small round opening
letter.mouth.v: Top teeth on bottom lip, voice on (like F but buzzing)
letter.mouth.aa: Round open mouth ‚Äî like saying 'oh' but wider
letter.mouth.ae: Open mouth, tongue low ‚Äî between A and E
letter.mouth.oe: Push lips forward, tongue high ‚Äî like saying EE with round lips
letter.mode.coarticulation_desc: Practice smooth transitions between consonants and vowels ‚Äî core motor planning
letter.coartic_instruction: üó£Ô∏è Tap each combo to practice smooth sound transitions!

break.step.feel_feet: Feel your feet on the ground
break.step.feel_legs: Notice your legs ‚Äî are they tense?
break.step.feel_stomach: Feel your stomach ‚Äî let it relax
break.step.feel_hands: Notice your hands ‚Äî open them wide
break.step.look_5_see: Look around ‚Äî name 5 things you can SEE
break.step.hear_3: Listen ‚Äî name 3 things you can HEAR
break.step.touch_toes: Bend down and touch your toes
break.step.neck_circles: Gentle neck circles ‚Äî slow and easy
break.step.feet_on_floor: Press your feet firmly on the floor
break.step.name_room: Name everything you see in the room
break.step.say_safe: Say: I am safe. I am here.

energy.strat.1: Rest, cozy blanket, quiet music, drink water, ask for a hug
energy.strat.2: You're in a great zone! Keep doing what you're doing.
energy.strat.3: Perfect energy for learning and playing! Channel it into something fun.
energy.strat.4: Time to slow down. Try deep breaths, squeeze a stress ball, or take a short walk.
energy.strat.5: Stop and breathe. Find a quiet space. Count to 10. Ask an adult for help if needed.

guide.step.sweater: Put on a sweater if cold
guide.step.books: Put your books in the bag

takk.title: TAKK Signs
takk.description: Signs as Alternative and Augmentative Communication (TAKK) ‚Äî sign the key words while speaking
takk.sign.ja: Nod fist up and down (like knocking)
takk.sign.nej: Shake flat hand side to side
takk.sign.slut: Both hands open, push away from body
takk.sign.hjalp: Fist on open palm, lift upward
takk.sign.vill: Point forward with index finger, pull toward chest
takk.sign.inte: Flat hand, sweep sideways away from body
takk.sign.jag: Point to yourself with index finger
takk.sign.ata: Pinch fingers to thumb, move to mouth
takk.sign.dricka: C-hand shape, tip to mouth (like drinking)
takk.sign.lasa: Flat hands open like a book
takk.sign.glad: Hands circle upward on chest (happy feeling)
takk.sign.arg: Claw hand in front of face, tense expression
takk.sign.trott: Both hands on chest, drop downward
takk.sign.katt: Pinch and pull whiskers from cheeks

socialStories.title: Social Stories
socialStories.school.1: It is morning. Time to get ready for school.
socialStories.school.2: I pack my bag with everything I need.
socialStories.school.3: I say hello to my teacher and friends.
socialStories.school.4: We learn new things in class. It is fun.
socialStories.school.5: At lunchtime, I eat my food and play.
socialStories.school.6: School is over. I go home. It was a good day!
socialStories.doctor.1: Today I am going to the doctor.
socialStories.doctor.3: I wait in the waiting room. I can read a book.
socialStories.doctor.4: The doctor is nice. They check that I am healthy.
socialStories.store.3: I help find things and put them in the cart.
socialStories.store.5: We go home with our bags. Good job!
socialStories.friend.1: My friend is coming to play!
socialStories.friend.3: I say hello and we decide what to play.
socialStories.friend.4: We take turns and share. That is kind.
socialStories.friend.5: We say goodbye. It was fun!
socialStories.haircut.1: Today I am getting a haircut.
socialStories.haircut.2: I sit in the chair. It is like a throne!
socialStories.haircut.3: The hairdresser cuts a little bit. It does not hurt.
socialStories.haircut.4: I look great! I did it!

about.title: About
about.tagline: Free apps for children with neurodevelopmental conditions, language disorders and intellectual disabilities
about.description: A free collection of evidence-based apps designed for children with neurodevelopmental conditions (NPF/NDD), intellectual disabilities (IF/ID), and speech-language difficulties. All apps work offline, are accessible, and use proven methods like AAC, TEACCH, PECS and LAMP.
about.audience.children: Children with NPF (autism, ADHD), intellectual disabilities, DLD, or verbal dyspraxia
about.audience.teachers: Special education teachers and school staff
about.feat.pwa: Works offline ‚Äî install on any device
about.feat.i18n: Swedish and English (more languages coming via Transifex)
about.feat.a11y: Accessible: large touch targets, high contrast
about.feat.privacy: No tracking, no ads, no data collection
about.credit.signs: Swedish Sign Language (CC BY-NC-SA 4.0, Stockholm University)
welcome.talkBoard.purpose: Talk Board is a comprehensive AAC communication board built on core vocabulary principles with LAMP (Language Acquisition through Motor Planning) consistent motor patterns. Fitzgerald Key color-coding (yellow for people, green for verbs, orange for nouns, blue for descriptors) provides grammatical visual structure.
welcome.talkBoard.how: Tap pictograms to speak individual words, or build multi-word sentences in the strip at the top. Button positions remain fixed following LAMP principles, so repeated use builds automatic motor patterns ‚Äî the child learns where each word "lives" through muscle memory rather than visual search.
welcome.talkBoard.goal: Give children a reliable, always-available voice through a well-organized AAC system. The combination of core vocabulary (the most frequently used words across all contexts), consistent motor planning (LAMP), and color-coded grammar (Fitzgerald Key) creates an efficient, scalable communication tool that grows with the child.
welcome.boardBuilder.purpose: Board Builder is a flexible AAC tool that lets parents and educators create fully customized communication boards using ARASAAC pictograms. Grounded in AAC best practices, it supports both core vocabulary and topic-specific layouts to match each child's unique communication needs.
welcome.boardBuilder.how: Choose your grid size, search the extensive ARASAAC pictogram library, then drag and drop symbols to arrange your board. Boards can be saved, edited and shared. The intuitive interface means no technical expertise is needed ‚Äî create a board in minutes and start using it immediately.
welcome.boardBuilder.goal: Empower educators and families to create individually tailored communication aids without relying on expensive commercial solutions. Custom boards ensure the vocabulary is relevant to the child's daily life, increasing both motivation and communicative success.
welcome.situationCards.purpose: Situation Cards provides pre-made, themed communication boards for common everyday situations like meals, playground time, school activities and doctor visits. Having situation-specific vocabulary ready reduces communication barriers in contexts where children most need support.
welcome.situationCards.how: Choose a situation from the library, and a themed board with relevant pictograms appears ready to use. Cards cover the vocabulary most needed in that specific context ‚Äî for example, food and drink choices at mealtimes, or playground equipment and social phrases for recess.
welcome.situationCards.goal: Enable functional communication in real-world situations by providing context-appropriate vocabulary without requiring custom board creation. Situation-specific AAC boards are recommended for children who are learning to communicate, as they reduce symbol search time and focus on the most relevant vocabulary.
welcome.talkingMat.purpose: Talking Mats is a digital implementation of the Talking Mats‚Ñ¢ framework ‚Äî a research-validated tool for helping people with communication difficulties express their views and preferences. By sorting pictures into simple categories, children can communicate opinions even with very limited speech.
welcome.talkingMat.how: A topic is presented with related picture cards. The child drags each card to one of three zones: green (like/positive), yellow (unsure/neutral), or red (dislike/negative). This simple sorting mechanism requires no speech or writing, making it accessible for children with severe communication difficulties.
welcome.talkingMat.goal: Ensure that every child's voice is heard in decisions affecting their life, regardless of speech ability. Talking Mats research demonstrates that this visual framework significantly improves the quality and quantity of information people with communication difficulties can express about their views and preferences.
welcome.pecsTrainer.purpose: PECS Trainer guides the early phases of picture exchange communication in a structured, systematic way. Based on the PECS protocol developed by Frost and Bondy, it teaches children that handing over a picture results in receiving the desired item ‚Äî the foundational communication skill.
welcome.pecsTrainer.how: The child selects a picture representing something they want and "exchanges" it with a communication partner through the app. The structured sequence reinforces the communicative function of the exchange. Progression follows PECS phases, from single picture exchanges to discriminating between multiple symbols.
welcome.pecsTrainer.goal: Build the fundamental understanding that communication is purposeful ‚Äî that initiating an exchange leads to a result. This cause-and-effect learning is the cornerstone of the PECS methodology and provides a foundation for all further communication development.
welcome.pointTalk.purpose: Point Talk implements aided language stimulation (also known as aided language modeling), an evidence-based AAC strategy where communication partners point to symbols while speaking. This teaches children that pictures carry meaning and can be used to communicate.
welcome.pointTalk.how: Display picture boards while talking with the child. As you speak, point to the relevant pictures on screen. The child learns to associate pictures with words by watching your model, then gradually begins pointing independently. The app provides organized symbol sets for common conversational topics.
welcome.pointTalk.goal: Stimulate language development through partner-modeled AAC use. Research shows that aided language stimulation ‚Äî where adults consistently model symbol use alongside speech ‚Äî significantly increases children's own use of symbols for communication. It's a cornerstone of naturalistic AAC intervention.
welcome.phraseBuilder.purpose: Phrase Builder is an AAC tool that helps children construct multi-word messages by combining pictograms in sequence. It bridges the gap between single-symbol communication and full sentence production, supporting language development at the phrase and sentence level.
welcome.phraseBuilder.how: Select pictograms from organized categories and place them in order to build a phrase or sentence. The completed sequence can be played back as speech. Visual layout follows left-to-right sentence structure, reinforcing word order and syntactic patterns.
welcome.phraseBuilder.goal: Develop the ability to combine symbols into meaningful multi-word expressions, progressing beyond single-word communication. This aligns with natural language development stages and supports children in expressing increasingly complex thoughts, needs and ideas through their AAC system.
welcome.pecsBoard.purpose: PECS Board provides ready-made communication boards organized by everyday needs, feelings and activities. Based on the Picture Exchange Communication System methodology, it offers an immediate AAC solution for children who need picture-based communication support without requiring custom setup.
welcome.pecsBoard.how: Navigate through pre-organized categories covering basic needs, emotions, common activities and social phrases. Tap any pictogram to have it spoken aloud, or combine multiple pictures on the sentence strip to express more complex messages. Categories follow functional communication priorities.
welcome.pecsBoard.goal: Provide immediate access to functional communication through organized picture boards. For families just starting with AAC, pre-made boards offer a quick entry point while the child and communication partners learn the picture exchange process together.
welcome.conversationAid.purpose: Conversation Aid provides pre-made phrases and visual scripts for common social situations. Designed for children who find spontaneous conversation difficult due to social communication challenges, it reduces the cognitive load of real-time language production.
welcome.conversationAid.how: Select a conversation context (greeting someone, asking for help, joining play, etc.), browse through suggested phrases organized by topic, and tap any phrase to have it spoken aloud. Phrases can be customized and new situations can be added.
welcome.conversationAid.goal: Reduce social anxiety by providing a safety net of prepared phrases that children can use or adapt. Visual scripts are an evidence-based strategy for supporting pragmatic language skills in children with autism, helping them participate more confidently in social interactions.
welcome.socialStories.purpose: Social Stories presents illustrated narratives that explain everyday social situations step by step ‚Äî a method developed by Carol Gray and widely used in autism education. Each story describes what happens, how people might feel, and what the child can do, reducing anxiety through understanding.
welcome.socialStories.how: Read stories together with the child, using the pictures and simple text to discuss what happens in different social situations. Stories cover common scenarios like going to school, visiting the doctor, playing with others, and handling changes in routine. New stories can be created for specific situations.
welcome.socialStories.goal: Prepare children for social situations and reduce anxiety through predictability and understanding. Social Stories have extensive research support for improving social comprehension and behavior in children with autism, by providing explicit instruction in the unwritten social rules that neurotypical children learn implicitly.
welcome.signDictionary.purpose: Sign Dictionary teaches key-word signing (TAKK ‚Äî Tecken som Alternativ och Kompletterande Kommunikation) through a searchable video library. TAKK uses manual signs alongside speech to support comprehension and expression, and is widely used with children who have language delays and autism.
welcome.signDictionary.how: Search for words to find their corresponding TAKK signs demonstrated in clear video clips. Each entry shows the sign from multiple angles with slow-motion replay available. Signs are organized by category for browsing, making it easy to learn signs for specific contexts like mealtime or school.
welcome.signDictionary.goal: Provide families and educators with an accessible reference for learning and practicing TAKK signs. Multi-modal communication ‚Äî combining speech, signs and pictures ‚Äî gives children more ways to understand and be understood, and research shows that signing supports rather than hinders spoken language development.
welcome.dayPlanner.purpose: Day Planner creates visual daily schedules with timeline support, helping children with autism understand what will happen and when. Predictability is crucial for reducing anxiety, and visual schedules are one of the most well-evidenced TEACCH strategies for structured support.
welcome.dayPlanner.how: Add activities using pictures and optional time markers, then arrange them in order by dragging. During the day, the child checks off completed activities, providing a clear sense of progress. The visual timeline makes abstract time concepts concrete and manageable.
welcome.dayPlanner.goal: Create security and reduce anxiety through clear visual structure and predictability. Visual schedules have strong research support for children with autism ‚Äî they reduce transition difficulties, increase on-task behavior, and promote independence by letting the child follow the plan without constant verbal prompting.
welcome.pictureSchedule.purpose: Picture Schedule creates simple, clear visual daily schedules using pictures ‚Äî a fundamental TEACCH strategy for children with autism. Visual schedules are among the most well-researched and effective interventions for increasing predictability and reducing anxiety.
welcome.pictureSchedule.how: Select pictures representing each activity in the day and arrange them in top-to-bottom order. As the child completes each activity, they check it off ‚Äî providing a concrete sense of progress and helping with transitions to the next activity.
welcome.pictureSchedule.goal: Increase independence and reduce transition-related anxiety through visual structure the child can follow on their own. TEACCH-based visual schedules help children understand what's happening, what's coming next, and what's already finished ‚Äî answering the questions that cause most anxiety.
welcome.mySchedule.purpose: My Schedule is a flexible visual schedule tool that can be fully customized to each child's individual needs and preferences. Drawing on TEACCH visual structuring principles, it provides predictability through personalized visual routines that the child can own and follow.
welcome.mySchedule.how: Build the schedule using the child's own activity pictures, preferred colors and familiar labels. Activities can include photos, pictograms or text. The layout adapts to different needs ‚Äî vertical lists, horizontal timelines, or grid views ‚Äî so every child gets a format that works for them.
welcome.mySchedule.goal: Provide a truly individualized visual schedule that reflects the child's actual daily life. Research consistently shows that personalized visual schedules are more effective than generic ones, as familiar images and routines increase comprehension, engagement and independent schedule-following.
welcome.routineBuddy.purpose: Routine Buddy provides visual step-by-step guides for daily routines like morning preparation, evening wind-down and school transitions. Based on visual task analysis ‚Äî a TEACCH and ABA strategy ‚Äî it breaks complex multi-step routines into manageable individual actions.
welcome.routineBuddy.how: Select a routine (morning, evening, school, etc.) and follow along step by step. Each step shows a clear picture with a brief instruction. The child progresses through steps at their own pace, checking off each one as completed. Routines can be customized with personal photos.
welcome.routineBuddy.goal: Build independence in daily routines by replacing verbal prompts with visual supports the child can follow alone. Visual task analysis reduces reliance on adult cueing, promotes self-management skills, and helps children internalize routine sequences through consistent, structured repetition.
welcome.stepGuide.purpose: Step Guide breaks complex tasks into clear, numbered visual steps ‚Äî a digital implementation of visual task analysis used in both TEACCH and ABA approaches. Any multi-step task that overwhelms a child can be made manageable with the right visual breakdown.
welcome.stepGuide.how: Create a guide by adding steps with pictures and short instructions. Each step is presented individually with a clear image and minimal text. The child follows one step at a time, checking off each as completed. Guides can be saved and reused for recurring tasks.
welcome.stepGuide.goal: Make complex, overwhelming tasks achievable by breaking them into small, clear, visual steps. Task analysis is one of the most versatile tools in autism education ‚Äî it reduces cognitive load, supports executive function difficulties, and builds independence by replacing verbal instructions with persistent visual support.
welcome.visualSupport.purpose: Visual Support provides ready-made and customizable visual schedules for common daily activities. Based on TEACCH visual structuring principles, it offers both pre-built routines for quick start and full customization for individual needs ‚Äî making evidence-based visual supports accessible to every family.
welcome.visualSupport.how: Choose from a library of pre-made routines (brushing teeth, getting dressed, homework, etc.) or create your own from scratch. Each routine presents steps with clear pictures and brief text instructions. Follow the steps in order, checking off each one as completed.
welcome.visualSupport.goal: Increase predictability and reduce reliance on verbal instructions through persistent visual supports. TEACCH research demonstrates that visual schedules and task sequences help children with autism process information more effectively, leading to greater independence and fewer behavioral challenges.
welcome.clothesChooser.purpose: Clothes Chooser supports independent dressing by providing visual guidance on weather-appropriate clothing. For children with autism who may have difficulty with executive planning or sensory preferences around clothing, this app reduces the daily struggle of getting dressed.
welcome.clothesChooser.how: The app displays current weather conditions with clear visual indicators, then suggests appropriate clothing items using pictures. Children can see what to wear layer by layer, making the abstract concept of "dressing for the weather" concrete and predictable.
welcome.clothesChooser.goal: Increase independence in daily self-care routines by removing the guesswork from clothing choices. Visual supports for dressing routines are a well-established TEACCH strategy, helping children build autonomy while reducing conflict and anxiety around getting ready.
welcome.cookingHelper.purpose: Cooking Helper breaks down recipes into clear, visual step-by-step instructions designed for children with autism and intellectual disabilities. Cooking is a powerful life skill that also practices sequencing, following instructions, and sensory exploration.
welcome.cookingHelper.how: Choose a recipe, then follow along one step at a time. Each step features a large, clear picture alongside a short written instruction. The child only sees one step at a time, reducing visual clutter and cognitive load ‚Äî a key TEACCH principle for structured teaching.
welcome.cookingHelper.goal: Enable meaningful participation in cooking activities through visual task analysis. Breaking complex tasks into individual steps with picture support is a proven strategy for building independence, and cooking provides natural opportunities to practice math, reading and fine motor skills.
welcome.visualTimer.purpose: Visual Timer provides countdown timers with first-then boards, combining two powerful visual support tools. The timer makes the abstract concept of remaining time visible, while the first-then display answers the crucial question "what happens after this?" ‚Äî reducing transition anxiety.
welcome.visualTimer.how: Set a countdown time and optionally add a "then" activity. The timer displays remaining time as a shrinking visual indicator (pie chart or bar), making time passage concrete. When the timer ends, the "then" picture is highlighted, smoothing the transition to the next activity.
welcome.visualTimer.goal: Make time visible and transitions predictable ‚Äî two interventions with strong evidence for reducing anxiety in children with autism. Visual timers reduce challenging behavior during transitions, and first-then boards provide the predictability that helps children accept activity changes without distress.
welcome.timeTracker.purpose: Time Tracker helps children develop time awareness by visually showing how long activities take. Understanding the passage of time is challenging for many children with autism, and visual duration tracking makes this abstract concept concrete and observable.
welcome.timeTracker.how: Start the timer when beginning an activity and stop it when finished. Elapsed time is displayed visually with filling progress bars or growing indicators, making the invisible passage of time visible. Over time, children can compare how long different activities take.
welcome.timeTracker.goal: Build temporal awareness and time estimation skills that support daily planning and self-management. Understanding how long things take helps children with transitions, scheduling and developing realistic expectations ‚Äî important executive function skills for increasing independence.
welcome.clockTeacher.purpose: Clock Teacher helps children learn to read both analog and digital clocks through interactive, multi-sensory exercises. Time concepts are particularly challenging for many children with autism and intellectual disabilities, and this app breaks the skill into manageable, visual steps.
welcome.clockTeacher.how: Children interact with a realistic clock face by dragging the hands to set times, answering questions about displayed times, and matching analog to digital formats. Immediate visual and auditory feedback reinforces correct answers, while difficulty progresses gradually from full hours to minutes.
welcome.clockTeacher.goal: Build practical time-telling skills that support independence in daily life. Understanding time is foundational for following schedules, managing transitions, and developing temporal awareness ‚Äî all areas where children with neurodevelopmental conditions often need targeted support.
welcome.breakCheck.purpose: Break Check provides structured break reminders designed for children who struggle with self-regulation and sensory processing. Based on sensory integration principles, it helps prevent cognitive overload by prompting regular pauses with guided activity suggestions.
welcome.breakCheck.how: Set personalized break intervals based on the child's attention span. When it's break time, the app offers three types of activities: movement breaks for physical regulation, quiet rest for sensory recovery, or playful activities for re-engagement. Visual and auditory cues make transitions smooth.
welcome.breakCheck.goal: Prevent sensory and cognitive overload through proactive, scheduled breaks. Research shows that regular breaks improve sustained attention and reduce challenging behaviors in children with autism and ADHD. The app builds self-awareness about personal regulation needs.
welcome.practiceBoard.purpose: Practice Board helps children and families track skill practice sessions with visual progress displays. Consistent practice is key to mastering new skills, and seeing progress visually provides motivation and a sense of accomplishment for children who may struggle with abstract goals.
welcome.practiceBoard.how: Add skills or activities being practiced (speech exercises, daily routines, social skills, etc.) and mark each completed practice session. The board displays progress visually through growing charts, sticker collections, or filling progress bars ‚Äî making effort and improvement visible.
welcome.practiceBoard.goal: Make practice consistent and rewarding by providing clear visual feedback on effort and progress. For children with autism, visual documentation of progress helps build intrinsic motivation and shows that persistence leads to improvement ‚Äî an important lesson for developing a growth mindset.
welcome.schoolDay.purpose: School Day provides a visual school schedule that helps children with autism navigate the school day with confidence. Knowing what's happening now and what comes next reduces the uncertainty that often triggers anxiety and challenging behavior in school settings.
welcome.schoolDay.how: Add lessons, breaks and other school activities with pictures and times. The app highlights the current activity and shows what's coming next, providing the "now and next" structure recommended by autism education specialists. Transitions between activities are clearly signaled.
welcome.schoolDay.goal: Reduce school-related anxiety and improve transitions by making the school day predictable and visual. Visual school schedules are a cornerstone of inclusive education for children with autism, helping them feel secure, participate more fully, and manage the many transitions a school day requires.
welcome.emotionMap.purpose: Emotion Map helps children identify and communicate their feelings using visual supports. Many children with autism experience alexithymia ‚Äî difficulty recognizing and naming emotions ‚Äî and this app provides concrete visual anchors for abstract emotional experiences.
welcome.emotionMap.how: Children select from illustrated emotion cards showing facial expressions and body language. A body map feature lets them indicate where they physically feel the emotion, strengthening the mind-body connection. Each emotion includes simple explanations of what might cause that feeling.
welcome.emotionMap.goal: Develop emotional literacy and interoceptive awareness ‚Äî the ability to recognize what's happening inside your body. These skills are foundational for self-regulation and social interaction, and visual emotion tools are recommended as part of comprehensive autism support programs.
welcome.calmRoom.purpose: The Calm Room is a digital sensory space offering calming activities for children experiencing stress, anxiety or sensory overload. Inspired by sensory rooms used in therapeutic settings, it provides on-demand tools for self-regulation that children can access independently.
welcome.calmRoom.how: Children choose from a menu of calming activities including guided deep breathing exercises, soothing ambient sounds, and mesmerizing visual patterns. Each activity is designed to engage a different sensory channel, helping the child find what works best for them in the moment.
welcome.calmRoom.goal: Provide accessible self-regulation tools that children can use anywhere ‚Äî at home, in school, or on the go. By offering multiple sensory modalities, the app helps children discover their own calming preferences, building long-term emotional regulation skills and reducing dependence on adult support.
welcome.focusBuddy.purpose: Focus Buddy uses structured work intervals with visual timers and reward systems to help children sustain attention on tasks. Based on the Pomodoro technique adapted for younger learners, it makes focused work manageable and motivating for children with attention difficulties.
welcome.focusBuddy.how: Set a focus period appropriate for the child's attention span (starting short and building up). A visual timer counts down while the child works. Completed focus sessions earn rewards, providing positive reinforcement that builds intrinsic motivation over time.
welcome.focusBuddy.goal: Gradually extend sustained attention through structured practice with positive reinforcement. Short, successful focus sessions build confidence and the experience of completion, which is especially valuable for children with autism and ADHD who often struggle with task persistence.
welcome.energyMeter.purpose: Energy Meter helps children track their energy and arousal levels throughout the day, inspired by the "Zones of Regulation" framework. Understanding personal energy patterns is key to self-regulation, but many children with autism need visual tools to develop this awareness.
welcome.energyMeter.how: At regular intervals, the child marks their current energy level using a simple visual scale. Over time, the app displays patterns showing when energy is typically high or low, helping children and caregivers plan activities around natural energy rhythms.
welcome.energyMeter.goal: Build interoceptive awareness and self-regulation skills by making invisible internal states visible and trackable. Understanding personal energy patterns helps with activity planning, predicting difficult times of day, and proactively using regulation strategies.
welcome.angerManager.purpose: The Anger Thermometer helps children recognize and regulate anger before it escalates. Based on cognitive-behavioral principles used in emotion regulation therapy, it provides a visual scale that makes abstract emotional intensity concrete and measurable ‚Äî essential for children with autism who may struggle with interoception.
welcome.angerManager.how: The child moves a visual thermometer to show their current anger level. Based on the selected intensity, the app suggests age-appropriate calming strategies such as deep breathing, counting, or physical movement. Over time, children learn to identify early warning signs and apply strategies independently.
welcome.angerManager.goal: Build emotional self-regulation skills by connecting internal feelings to visible cues and actionable strategies. Regular use helps children develop a personal toolkit for managing anger, reducing meltdowns and increasing emotional resilience in everyday situations.
welcome.rewardChart.purpose: Reward Chart uses visual token systems based on Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) principles of positive reinforcement. Children earn stars or tokens for demonstrating target behaviors or achieving goals, making abstract progress concrete and motivating.
welcome.rewardChart.how: Set specific, achievable goals with the child. Each time a goal is met, add a star to the chart. When enough stars are collected, the child earns a predetermined reward. Visual progress toward the reward maintains motivation, and the clear structure helps children understand behavioral expectations.
welcome.rewardChart.goal: Motivate positive behavior change through structured positive reinforcement. Token economy systems have extensive research support for children with autism, helping establish new behaviors, routines and social skills through clear expectations and consistent, visual reward tracking.
welcome.diary.purpose: The Visual Diary gives children a private, accessible way to reflect on their day using pictures, emojis and text. For children with limited written language, the multi-modal input options ensure everyone can express their experiences and feelings.
welcome.diary.how: Each entry can combine free text, selected emojis for emotions, and pictures (from the library or camera). Previous entries are saved and can be reviewed, helping children see patterns in their experiences and emotions over time.
welcome.diary.goal: Support emotional processing and self-reflection through regular journaling practice. Reviewing diary entries with a parent or therapist can facilitate conversations about feelings and experiences, building narrative skills and emotional vocabulary in a low-pressure context.
welcome.wordBuilder.purpose: Word Builder develops early literacy skills by having children spell words letter by letter with picture and audio support. This multi-sensory approach to spelling connects visual word recognition, phonemic awareness and motor letter sequencing ‚Äî key components of structured literacy instruction.
welcome.wordBuilder.how: A picture is shown and the word is spoken aloud. The child then drags letters into the correct order to spell the word. Letters can be tapped to hear their sounds, supporting phoneme-grapheme correspondence. Difficulty progresses from short, common words to longer, more complex ones.
welcome.wordBuilder.goal: Build spelling and word recognition skills through active, multi-sensory practice. For children with language disorders and autism, this hands-on approach to literacy ‚Äî seeing the picture, hearing the word, and physically constructing it letter by letter ‚Äî creates stronger memory traces than passive exposure alone.
welcome.sentenceBuilder.purpose: Sentence Builder teaches sentence construction using color-coded word categories inspired by the Fitzgerald Key system. By assigning consistent colors to grammatical roles (subjects, verbs, objects, descriptors), it makes sentence structure visible and predictable for children with language disorders.
welcome.sentenceBuilder.how: Words are presented in color-coded groups matching their grammatical function. Children select words in the correct order to build complete sentences, guided by the color pattern. Completed sentences are read aloud, providing auditory feedback that reinforces the connection between word order and meaning.
welcome.sentenceBuilder.goal: Strengthen syntactic awareness and sentence-building skills through visual grammar support. The Fitzgerald Key color system is a proven tool in AAC and language therapy, helping children internalize sentence patterns by associating grammatical roles with consistent visual cues.
welcome.letterJourney.purpose: Letter Journey teaches letter recognition and phonemic awareness through multi-sensory learning ‚Äî seeing the letter, hearing its sound, and watching formation animations. This multi-modal approach is aligned with structured literacy methods recommended for children with language and learning difficulties.
welcome.letterJourney.how: Each letter is presented with its visual form, corresponding sound, and an animation showing how it's written. Children can trace the letter on screen for kinesthetic reinforcement. The progression follows phonemic complexity, starting with the most common and distinct sounds.
welcome.letterJourney.goal: Build solid phonemic awareness and letter knowledge as prerequisites for reading and writing. For children with language disorders and autism, explicit, systematic phonics instruction with multi-sensory reinforcement is the most effective approach to literacy development.
welcome.pictureDictionary.purpose: Picture Dictionary helps children build vocabulary through the powerful visual pairing of words with ARASAAC pictograms. Vocabulary development is a common challenge for children with language disorders, and visual-semantic mapping is an evidence-based strategy for strengthening word learning.
welcome.pictureDictionary.how: Browse categories of everyday words, each shown with a clear pictogram and the written word. A self-testing mode lets children match words to pictures and pictures to words, reinforcing learning through active recall. Audio pronunciation supports children who are still developing reading skills.
welcome.pictureDictionary.goal: Expand receptive and expressive vocabulary through repeated, multi-sensory exposure to word-picture pairs. A strong vocabulary is essential for both communication and literacy, and the categorized format helps children build organized mental word maps (semantic networks).
welcome.mathAid.purpose: Math Aid makes basic arithmetic concrete and visual by letting children manipulate on-screen objects to solve problems. Following the concrete-representational-abstract (CRA) progression, it bridges the gap between physical manipulatives and abstract number operations.
welcome.mathAid.how: Children solve addition, subtraction and comparison problems by counting, dragging and grouping visual objects. Each problem is presented with picture support, and the child can physically move objects to find the answer before selecting it. Difficulty adapts to the child's level.
welcome.mathAid.goal: Build mathematical understanding through visual, hands-on problem solving rather than rote memorization. For children with autism and intellectual disabilities, connecting math operations to concrete visual representations leads to deeper understanding and better generalization.
welcome.counting.purpose: Visual Counting helps young children build foundational number sense by connecting concrete objects to abstract numbers. Using manipulable on-screen objects, it follows the concrete-representational-abstract (CRA) approach widely recommended for children with learning differences.
welcome.counting.how: Children tap on-screen objects to count them one by one. As each object is tapped, the corresponding number appears and is spoken aloud, reinforcing the one-to-one correspondence principle. Visual and auditory feedback supports multi-sensory learning.
welcome.counting.goal: Establish basic numeracy skills through multi-sensory engagement. Understanding quantity-number relationships is the foundation for all later mathematical learning, and children with autism and intellectual disabilities benefit greatly from the repeated, visual practice this app provides.
welcome.moneyCheck.purpose: Money Check teaches practical money skills ‚Äî recognizing coins and bills, counting amounts, and calculating change. Financial literacy is an essential life skill, and children with intellectual disabilities and autism benefit from structured, visual practice before real-world application.
welcome.moneyCheck.how: Practice progresses from identifying individual coins and bills, through counting mixed amounts, to making purchases and calculating correct change. Each exercise uses realistic images of currency and provides immediate feedback with visual explanations of correct answers.
welcome.moneyCheck.goal: Build functional money skills that directly support independence in community settings. Understanding money is crucial for participation in everyday activities like shopping, and structured practice with visual support helps children internalize concepts they'll use throughout their lives.
welcome.memoryGame.purpose: The Memory Game offers classic card-matching gameplay designed to train working memory, visual attention, and concentration. These cognitive skills are foundational for learning and daily functioning, and game-based practice keeps children motivated and engaged.
welcome.memoryGame.how: Flip cards to reveal pictures and find matching pairs. Grid sizes and the number of pairs can be adjusted to match the child's ability level ‚Äî start with just a few pairs and gradually increase difficulty. Clean visual design minimizes sensory distractions.
welcome.memoryGame.goal: Strengthen working memory and sustained attention through enjoyable, repeatable practice. Working memory is a core executive function that supports learning across all domains, and children with autism and ADHD often benefit from targeted, game-based cognitive training.
welcome.soundLibrary.purpose: Sound Library offers an organized collection of environmental, animal and musical sounds designed to develop auditory attention and sound-meaning associations. For children with autism who may have atypical auditory processing, controlled sound exploration builds listening skills in a safe, predictable way.
welcome.soundLibrary.how: Browse sound categories including animals, nature, instruments, vehicles and household items. Tap any item to hear its sound while seeing the corresponding picture. The predictable, child-controlled playback lets children explore sounds at their own pace without unexpected auditory surprises.
welcome.soundLibrary.goal: Strengthen auditory discrimination, attention and sound-image associations through self-directed exploration. These foundational listening skills support both language development and environmental awareness, and the categorized format helps children build organized auditory-semantic connections.
welcome.chooser.purpose: The Chooser helps children who find decision-making overwhelming by turning choices into a visual, structured process. For many children with autism, open-ended choices cause anxiety ‚Äî this app reduces that stress by presenting options clearly and adding an element of playfulness.
welcome.chooser.how: Add alternatives using pictures, text or both. The app can spin a wheel, draw randomly, or let the child eliminate options one by one. This multi-modal approach accommodates different cognitive styles and helps the child feel in control of the process.
welcome.chooser.goal: Reduce choice-related anxiety and build independent decision-making skills. By making the selection process visual and structured, children gradually learn to evaluate options and make choices ‚Äî a key executive function skill that supports independence in daily life.
rewards.title: Rewards
rewards.no_stars_yet: No gold stars yet ‚Äî keep practising and they'll come!
rewards.no_diplomas_yet: No diplomas yet. Unlock achievements to earn diplomas!
rewards.goal_reward_placeholder: What happens at the goal? (e.g. ice cream!)
rewards.diploma.title: Diploma
rewards.achievement.first_star.desc: You got your very first gold star!
rewards.achievement.five_stars.desc: You've collected five gold stars ‚Äî fantastic!
rewards.achievement.ten_stars.desc: A whole ten gold stars ‚Äî you're amazing!
rewards.achievement.twenty_five_stars.de: 25 gold stars! You're a real star!
rewards.achievement.five_minutes.desc: You've practised for five minutes ‚Äî great start!
rewards.achievement.thirty_minutes.desc: Half an hour of practice ‚Äî what an achievement!
app.oral_motor.desc: Practice oral motor movements for speech ‚Äî tongue, lips, jaw and breathing
app.sound_chain.desc: Chain sounds together into syllables and words ‚Äî visual chain links
app.speech_practice.desc: Structured speech training with the DTTC method ‚Äî listen, imitate, practice
app.syllable_jump.desc: Jump through syllables ‚Äî clap the rhythm and build words
welcome.oralMotor.purpose: Oral Motor Training provides structured exercises for developing the motor control needed for clear speech. Specifically designed for children with childhood apraxia of speech (CAS) and other motor speech disorders, it targets the planning and coordination of speech movements.
welcome.oralMotor.how: Choose an exercise group targeting tongue, lips, jaw or breathing control. The app guides through each exercise with clear visual demonstrations and spoken instructions, progressing from simple isolated movements to more complex coordinated sequences needed for speech.
welcome.oralMotor.goal: Build the foundation of motor speech control through systematic, guided practice. For children with CAS and neurodevelopmental conditions, regular oral motor exercise supports the development of muscle memory and movement patterns that underpin intelligible speech production.
welcome.soundChain.purpose: Sound Chain helps children with childhood apraxia of speech (CAS) practice combining individual sounds into syllables and words. Based on coarticulation principles central to motor speech therapy, it trains the smooth transitions between sounds that are the hallmark of fluent speech.
welcome.soundChain.how: Start with individual phonemes displayed as visual blocks. Tap to hear each sound, then chain them together by connecting blocks into syllable and word sequences. The app emphasizes smooth transitions between sounds rather than isolated production, reflecting how connected speech actually works.
welcome.soundChain.goal: Develop the ability to plan and execute smooth sound sequences ‚Äî a core deficit in childhood apraxia of speech. By practicing coarticulation (the blending of one sound into the next), children build the motor programs needed for intelligible, fluent speech production.
welcome.speechPractice.purpose: Speech Practice implements the core DTTC (Dynamic Temporal and Tactile Cueing) methodology for children with childhood apraxia of speech. It provides the systematic, high-repetition practice structure that DTTC research identifies as essential for building speech motor programs.
welcome.speechPractice.how: Follow the DTTC progression: first listen to the model carefully, then imitate simultaneously (speaking together), then with a slight delay, and finally produce the target independently. Each level is practiced with high repetition before moving to the next, building motor automaticity step by step.
welcome.speechPractice.goal: Build speech motor automatization through the systematic cueing hierarchy central to DTTC therapy. The progression from simultaneous imitation to independent production gradually transfers motor planning responsibility to the child, developing the reliable speech motor programs needed for spontaneous communication.
welcome.syllableJump.purpose: Syllable Jump develops syllable awareness and rhythmic speech planning through multi-sensory syllable segmentation exercises. For children with CAS, syllable-level practice is a crucial bridge between individual sounds and whole words, training the rhythmic timing of speech.
welcome.syllableJump.how: See a word displayed with its picture, then tap each syllable in sequence as you say it. Clapping along reinforces the rhythmic pattern. When all syllables are correctly tapped, the whole word plays back fluently. The multi-sensory combination of visual, auditory and motor input strengthens syllable representations.
welcome.syllableJump.goal: Build syllable awareness and rhythmic speech planning ‚Äî key skills for children with childhood apraxia of speech and phonological disorders. Understanding how words break into syllable beats supports both speech production and early reading skills (phonological awareness).
oralMotor.title: Oral Motor
oralMotor.intro: Choose an exercise to train your oral motor skills!
oralMotor.tongue.desc: Move your tongue in different directions
oralMotor.tongue.up: Lift your tongue up to the roof of your mouth
oralMotor.tongue.down: Stretch your tongue down toward your chin
oralMotor.tongue.left: Move your tongue to the left
oralMotor.tongue.right: Move your tongue to the right
oralMotor.tongue.circle: Move your tongue in a circle
oralMotor.lips.puckerSmile: Pucker and smile, pucker and smile
oralMotor.jaw.openClose: Open and close, open and close
oralMotor.jaw.side: Move your jaw to the side
soundChain.title: Sound Chain
soundChain.intro: Chain sounds together into words! Start simple and build up.
speechPractice.title: Speech Practice
speechPractice.intro: Practice speech step by step with the DTTC method!
speechPractice.stageDesc.model: Listen to the model ‚Äî hear how it should sound
speechPractice.stageDesc.simultaneous: Say it AT THE SAME TIME as the model
speechPractice.stageDesc.delayed: Wait a moment, then say it yourself
speechPractice.stageDesc.independent: Say it all by yourself without help!
syllableJump.title: Syllable Jump
syllableJump.intro: Break words into syllables ‚Äî tap and clap along!
app.sentence_strip.desc: Build sentences with PECS sentence strips (Phase IV-VI)
app.symbol_text.desc: Type text and see pictograms above each word
app.comm_book.desc: Digital communication book with tabs, photos and pictograms
sentenceStrip.title: Sentence Strip Workshop
sentenceStrip.hint: Choose a starter phrase and add words to build a sentence
symbolText.title: Symbol-Supported Text
commBook.title: Communication Book
welcome.sentenceStrip.purpose: Sentence Strip Workshop guides children through PECS Phases IV-VI, where learners progress from simple "I want" requests to complex sentences with attributes, expanded vocabulary, and spontaneous commenting. It provides structured digital practice for these critical communication milestones.
welcome.sentenceStrip.how: Select the appropriate PECS phase to match the child's current level. Choose a starter phrase ("I want," "I see," "I have"), then add words from categorized pictogram boards to complete the sentence. The completed strip is read aloud, and favorite sentences can be saved for quick reuse.
welcome.sentenceStrip.goal: Support progression through the advanced PECS phases where children learn to construct sentences, add descriptors, and comment on their environment. This structured practice builds the sentence-level communication skills that bridge picture exchange and more complex language use.
welcome.symbolText.purpose: Symbol Text automatically displays pictograms above written text, creating a symbol-supported reading experience inspired by Widgit Literacy. This dual representation helps children with autism, intellectual disabilities and reading difficulties access written content through visual support.
welcome.symbolText.how: Type or paste any sentence into the text box and tap "Show with symbols." The app matches each word to an ARASAAC pictogram and displays it above the text. The combined text-and-symbol display can be read aloud with text-to-speech, providing triple reinforcement: visual symbol, written word, and spoken audio.
welcome.symbolText.goal: Support reading comprehension by linking written words to visual symbols. Symbol-supported text is an evidence-based approach for developing literacy in children with intellectual disabilities and complex communication needs, providing a bridge between picture-based communication and independent text reading.
welcome.commBook.purpose: The Communication Book is a comprehensive digital AAC tool modeled on PECS communication books. It combines categorized ARASAAC pictograms with the ability to add personal photos, creating a personalized communication system that travels everywhere on a tablet or phone.
welcome.commBook.how: Navigate through category tabs (food, drinks, activities, feelings, etc.) to find the right symbol. Tap cards to add them to the sentence strip at the top, then press the speaker button to have the sentence spoken aloud. The edit mode lets you customize categories and add your own photos and words for maximum relevance.
welcome.commBook.goal: Provide a portable, always-available communication system that grows with the child. Based on the PECS framework, the book supports progression from single-symbol requests to multi-word sentences, giving non-verbal and minimally verbal children a reliable way to express needs, thoughts and feelings.
app.speech_rhythm.desc: Prosody and rhythm training for CAS ‚Äî tap along, stress patterns and intonation
app.sound_lottery.desc: Randomized phoneme practice ‚Äî spin the wheel and practice sounds in isolation ‚Üí syllable ‚Üí word ‚Üí sentence
app.mouth_gym.desc: Animated visual guides for tongue, lips and jaw ‚Äî based on PROMPT therapy
app.word_parade.desc: Minimal pairs ‚Äî words that differ by one sound. Critical phonological training
app.story_workshop.desc: Narrative speech practice ‚Äî build simple stories with picture sequences and practice telling them
app.the_mimic.desc: Listen and repeat with increasing complexity ‚Äî sounds ‚Üí words ‚Üí phrases ‚Üí sentences. Core DTTC technique
speechRhythm.title: Speech Rhythm
speechRhythm.intro: Practice the rhythm and melody of speech!
speechRhythm.tap.instruction: Tap the drum in time with the syllables!
speechRhythm.intonation.instruction: Follow the melody curve with your voice!
welcome.speechRhythm.purpose: Speech Rhythm trains prosody ‚Äî the stress, tempo and intonation patterns that give speech its natural melody. Prosodic difficulties are common in both autism and childhood apraxia of speech (CAS), and targeted rhythm practice improves both intelligibility and communicative naturalness.
welcome.speechRhythm.how: Listen to rhythmic speech patterns, then practice reproducing them while tapping along. A visual metronome provides timing support, and stress patterns are highlighted visually so children can see the rhythm as well as hear it. Exercises progress from simple two-syllable patterns to complex sentence-level prosody.
welcome.speechRhythm.goal: Improve the natural rhythm and melody of speech, which is essential for being understood and sounding natural. Prosody training is a key component of CAS therapy, and research shows that rhythmic cueing helps children with motor speech disorders produce more fluent, naturally-stressed speech.
soundLottery.title: Sound Lottery
soundLottery.intro: Spin the wheel and practice sounds!
welcome.soundLottery.purpose: Sound Lottery provides systematic phoneme practice using motivating randomization to keep drill-based exercises engaging. It follows the hierarchical progression used in articulation therapy ‚Äî from isolated sounds through syllables, words and sentences ‚Äî ensuring thorough practice at each level.
welcome.soundLottery.how: Spin the wheel to randomly select a target phoneme. Then practice it through a structured hierarchy: first in isolation, then in syllables (initial, medial, final positions), then in words, and finally in short sentences. The randomized selection adds an element of game-play to what is otherwise repetitive drill practice.
welcome.soundLottery.goal: Provide systematic, thorough practice of all speech sounds with built-in motivation through gamification. The hierarchical progression ensures children master each sound at simpler levels before attempting more complex contexts, following the standard approach in evidence-based articulation therapy.
mouthGym.title: Mouth Gym
welcome.mouthGym.purpose: Mouth Gym provides visually guided oral motor exercises based on principles from PROMPT therapy and oral motor intervention research. It targets the lip, tongue and jaw movements needed for clear speech production in children with motor speech disorders and neurodevelopmental conditions.
welcome.mouthGym.how: Select a muscle group (lips, tongue, jaw, or breathing), then follow step-by-step animated demonstrations. Each exercise includes a visual model showing correct placement and movement. The app is designed to be used alongside a mirror so children can see and compare their own movements.
welcome.mouthGym.goal: Strengthen the oral motor foundation needed for clear, intelligible speech. Oral motor exercises are a component of many speech therapy programs, and this app provides a structured home practice tool that children and parents can use between therapy sessions to maintain progress.
wordParade.title: Word Parade
wordParade.intro: Hear the difference between similar words!
welcome.wordParade.purpose: Word Parade provides minimal pair training ‚Äî practicing words that differ by just one sound (like "cat" and "hat"). This technique is fundamental in both articulation therapy and phonological intervention, training the ability to hear and produce the sound contrasts that distinguish word meanings.
welcome.wordParade.how: Listen to pairs of similar-sounding words and practice distinguishing between them. Then practice producing each word clearly, focusing on the contrasting sound. Exercises include listening discrimination ("which word did you hear?") and production practice with visual and auditory feedback.
welcome.wordParade.goal: Sharpen phonological awareness and speech accuracy by targeting the specific sound contrasts that the child finds difficult. Minimal pair therapy is one of the most well-researched approaches in speech-language pathology, with strong evidence for improving both perception and production of speech sounds.
storyWorkshop.title: Story Workshop
storyWorkshop.intro: Build a story and tell it!
welcome.storyWorkshop.purpose: Story Workshop targets the "connected speech" phase of DTTC therapy, where children progress from practicing individual words and phrases to producing coherent multi-sentence narratives. Building stories with picture support scaffolds this critical transition to functional, connected communication.
welcome.storyWorkshop.how: Select pictures and arrange them into a narrative sequence. Listen to a model telling the story, then practice retelling it independently. The visual story structure provides a scaffold that supports motor planning for longer utterances while the pictures serve as retrieval cues.
welcome.storyWorkshop.goal: Develop connected speech ‚Äî the ability to produce fluent, multi-sentence discourse ‚Äî which is the ultimate goal of speech therapy for CAS. Story-based practice provides meaningful context for combining the motor speech skills practiced in isolation into functional, real-world communication.
theMimic.title: The Mimic
theMimic.intro: Listen and mimic ‚Äî from simple to complex!
welcome.theMimic.purpose: The Mimic implements the core DTTC technique of simultaneous production and progressive distancing, where the child imitates a speech model with decreasing support. This structured imitation approach is the foundation of motor speech therapy for childhood apraxia of speech.
welcome.theMimic.how: Listen to the speech model, then mimic it immediately. Start with simple sounds and CV syllables, progressing through words, phrases and sentences as accuracy improves. The key is high repetition at each level ‚Äî practicing until production becomes automatic before moving to greater complexity.
welcome.theMimic.goal: Build speech motor programs through systematic imitation with high repetition. In DTTC methodology, the therapist (or app) provides the model and the child's repeated imitation gradually develops the motor plans needed for voluntary, independent speech production. Consistency and repetition are the keys to progress.
app.sagostunden.desc: Create fun stories by choosing words and pictures
sagostunden.pick_words_hint: Tap a word to add it, or skip to get a random one!
sagostunden.no_saved: No saved stories yet. Create one!
welcome.sagostunden.purpose: Story Time helps children practice narrative skills through visual storytelling using ARASAAC pictograms. Narrative ability ‚Äî telling coherent stories with a beginning, middle and end ‚Äî is a critical language milestone that many children with language disorders find challenging.
welcome.sagostunden.how: Choose a story template, then select words and characters using pictograms to fill in the blanks. The app generates a unique illustrated story that can be read aloud. This scaffolded approach lets children create stories even before they can write, building confidence and creativity.
welcome.sagostunden.goal: Develop narrative language skills including sequencing, character perspective, and story structure. Research shows that visual storytelling supports language comprehension and production in children with autism and language disorders, while the creative element keeps engagement high.
